name: clofazimine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?427
Reason: The basic structure for clofazimine includes multiple aromatic rings, nitrogen-containing heterocycles, chloro substituents, and an aliphatic chain with a tertiary amine. The presence of the aromatic rings contributes significantly to an increased melting point due to the stable and planar structure facilitating strong π-π interactions. For instance, benzene, the simplest aromatic compound, has a melting point of 5.5 °C, but substitution and extension of the ring system in compounds like naphtalene and anthracene increase the melting point considerably (80.2 °C and 216 °C, respectively). Moreover, nitrogen’s presence in heterocyclic rings can form additional intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which would further enhance the melting point, as seen in compounds such as pyridine (melting point: -42 °C) and pyrimidine (melting point: 20-22 °C). The -N=C- linkage in imines also strengthens the molecular rigidity, thus increasing the melting point. The two chloro substituents present on the aromatic rings enhance the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and potential for enhanced intermolecular interactions involving the chlorine electrons. Chlorobenzene itself (a single chloro substituent on benzene) has a melting point of -45.6 °C, but as part of a more complex and rigid system, each Cl substituent would contribute to an increased melting point. The aliphatic chain attached to a tertiary amine would contribute less to the melting point than the aromatic systems, since it adds flexibility to the structure and reduces the overall symmetry. Tertiary amines themselves typically have lower melting points (triethylamine has a melting point of -114.7 °C), but in the context of this molecule, the aliphatic chain's effect might be overshadowed by the larger, rigid planar structures. Given the structural complexity and provided comparisons, it would be reasonable to predict the melting point of clofazimine to be quite high. A rough approximation for each of the key features contributing to the melting point would be: aromatic rings (+150 °C), N-heterocycles (+20 °C per nitrogen), chloro substituents (+5 °C each), tertiary amine in aliphatic chain (-5 °C).
